message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and symptoms suggest tetralogy of Fallot. A boot-shaped heart is a characteristic finding on CXR in patients with this condition. Egg on a string is seen in patients with transposition of the great vessels, displaced tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, and atrial septal defect may cause an enlarged right heart but not a boot-shaped heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including rapid breathing, cyanosis, and delays in development, suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. A boot-shaped heart is a characteristic finding on chest X-ray in patients with Tetralogy of Fallot. The other three options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and symptoms suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a boot-shaped heart on CXR. A displaced tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, and an egg on a string appearance is seen in transposition of the great arteries. An atrial septal defect may not be visible on CXR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate a possible diagnosis of Tetralogy of Fallot, where the right ventricular outflow tract is obstructed. This will lead to a boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray (B). A displaced tricuspid valve (C) may be seen in Ebstein’s anomaly, but this doesn’t explain the other symptoms. An egg on a string (A) typically represents transposition of the great arteries, which is less likely given the presence of a systolic ejection murmur. An atrial septal defect (D) may cause a right-sided enlargement, but not a boot-shaped appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including delayed development, squatting after activity, and cyanosis, suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. The most commonly seen CXR finding in this condition is a boot-shaped heart due to the characteristic shape of the right ventricular outflow tract. Egg on a string appearance is seen in transposition of the great arteries. Displaced tricuspid valve and atrial septal defect are not typically seen on CXR in cases of Tetralogy of Fallot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest that the child may have Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border, cyanosis, frequent squatting, and delayed development. The "boot-shaped heart" appearance on CXR is a characteristic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot. Egg on a string is associated with transposition of the great arteries, displaced tricuspid valve is associated with Ebstein anomaly, and atrial septal defect does not typically present with severe cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is associated with a boot-shaped heart on CXR. Egg on a string appearance is associated with transposition of the great arteries, displaced tricuspid valve is associated with Ebstein anomaly, and atrial septal defect is not typically associated with severe cyanosis and delayed development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and symptoms suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes a boot-shaped heart on CXR. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a boot-shaped heart on CXR. Option A, "egg on a string," is characteristic of transposition of the great arteries. Option C, displaced tricuspid valve, is associated with Ebstein anomaly, and option D, atrial septal defect, may not be visible on CXR or may show an enlarged right heart border but not a boot-shaped heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a boot-shaped heart on CXR. None of the other options are associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.
